title: Will the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) program be implemented prior to inauguration day?

Obama has been reduced to being a lame duck president. Nothing new will happen prior to inauguration.

This is not legislation, it's an Executive order. It was blocked by a court injunction lat summer, and the Supreme Court deadlocked on the appeal, so the injunction stood. In order for this to be implemented, Obama would have to defy a court order forbidding implementation. If he did that, it would probably open up a new set of lawsuits that would keep the issue unresolved until after Trump's inauguration.

The supreme court ruling has pretty much guaranteed this won't happen during Obama's term in office http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/24/us/supreme-court-immigration-obama-dapa.html?_r=0.

If the current Prez is feeling especially feisty, he could tweak the provisions of this programme, taking very minimal note of the Sup Ct's objections, and promulgate it again under the same name, telling his agencies to begin implementation immediately.  What, after all, would he have to lose by doing this?  His Feistiness Quotient is creeping up marginally of late, but probably not enough for this actually to happen.  Could, though.

In theory, constitutional law professor and future Supreme Court Justice Obama will not defy a Supreme Court decision.  In practice, why the hell not?  It is wildly improbable, but not inconceivable, that he will reissue his executive order, or most of it, and instruct his minions to "implement" it, whatever the people who wrote this Q thinks that means.  Unlikely, but fun.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Here's a spanner for the works:  First week in January, Clinton has won the election, Garland or someone more liberal is or will be on the Supreme Court.  Obama reissues the order establishing DAPA and tells the cognizant agencies to get cracking on it, knowing that by the time it gets back to the Court it will likely be upheld.  This Q goes from 0 to 100 faster than your Lamborghini.
An injunction is in place, the Supreme Court won't break that, and it's dead in the water until United States v. Texas resolves in Judge Hanen's court.

Almost a month after the SCOTUS 4-4 tie in the case, which sent the DAPA back to the lower courts, effectively killing it, the Obama administration asked the Supreme Court to rehear the DAPA case after a new Supreme Court Justice is confirmed.  This is most likely just procedural and just in case as the odds of a new justice being sworn have not improved in the current political climate.

No - tied SC ruling handed down & now returns to the previous  lower 5th Circuit Court ruling which states the POTUS overstepped his authority. http://www.cfr.org/immigration/us-supreme-court-obamas-immigration-actions/p37630
This should not actually resolve until 1-21-2016. 4-4 Sup Ct decision

FOR the third time since the death of Antonin Scalia February, a stymied Supreme Court has split 4-4 and failed to come to a decision. Of the three ties, today's deadlock over United States v Texas, a challenge to Barack Obama’s immigration orders, carries the highest stakes. Up to 5m undocumented immigrants who were the intended beneficiaries of Mr Obama’s 2014 executive actions have lost their chance to apply for a programme that would have given them temporary permission to work and relief from deportation.
1% in case it is appealed to the OAS.
The Supreme Court's ruling means DAPA can't be implemented.

With today's SCOTUS ruling, the Obama Administration immigration plan remains blocked by the expected 4-4 Supreme Court tie. This means that the lower court injunction remains in place -- the judgement is affirmed by an equally divided court.
Does this question remain open until inauguration day?
Uh, gonna get a huge hit from basing my forecast on what Fantasy SCOTUS predicted :-)
Down 5% on the SCOTUS decision. I discount any likelihood of any extra-legal process on the Executive side. Still think the question probably should be continued until inauguration day.

http://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/15pdf/15-674_jhlo.pdf  US v. Texas
The Court ruled and the question is resolved.

"The judgment is affirmed by an equally divided Court"
So the injunction stands and DAPA cannot be implemented.

I  make mistakes. So apparently did the forecasters on Fantasyscotus and  "Marshall" the computer algorithm.
That market is not set up for a  8 person Court.
Marshall predicted 8-0 reversed on standing
Forecasters were at 5-3 but  as noted Kennedy was that 5th vote to reverse by a slim margin.
Thank @mparrault for that source.

If the decision is split along ideological lines (4-4), the matter will not set precedent and will be referred to the lower court from which it origination therefore defeating the president's agenda late into the end of the second term.   If outcome is (4-4), Texas and the other 22 states who have contested the President's executive action.

There are five different dates this month in which SCOTUS could render a decision on the DAPA reprieve.  Today, June 16 was the third of such dates.  Media was camping outside the Supreme Court just in case of a ruling.
Down a few points due to radio silence on this issue.
Lower court ruling will stand.  Our government will continue its kick the can down the road mentality.

After reading numerous articles on this subject, it does seem to come down to what a split court will decide.  As the lower court effectively struck down the executive action, we would need at least a 5-3 vote generally allowing to have this executive action proceed during the Obama administration.  From all of what I have read so far, a 4-4 split is most probable.  Therefore, I consider this to be a relatively low probability event.  Here is one article which seems to summarize my position quite well:
https://theweek.com/articles/619280/why-supreme-court-likely-strike-down-obamas-immigration-order--even-ties
Consensus has aggregated to 18%, good evidence the chances are lower than I originally forecast.
Only logic is republicans trying to get Hispanic vote and with Trump as the head of the ticket I can't see this on the platform
The Senate won't even give Merrick Garland the time of day - hard to see how they'll even let this issue come up for air.

With a little Judge Shopping...? Judge Andrew S. Hanen ordered remedial ethics classes for all department lawyers at headquarters in Washington who practice in any of the 26 states that sued over the amnesty — “taught by at least one recognized ethics expert who is unaffiliated with the Justice Department.”
The judge also ordered the Department of Homeland Security to turn over — by June 10th — identifying information for thousands of immigrants who entered the United States illegally and are now shielded from deportation under a government “deferred action” program. Note: we’re talking illegal immigrants here — people here illegally, in violating our nation’s rule of law.
Today, as the Washington Times reports, the Dept of Justice filed an emergency motion to fight back against the judge’s orders. It accused him of exceeding his authority,...http://www.allenbwest.com/michellejesse/obama-dept-of-justice-files-emergency-motion-the-reason-is-astounding
Texas will likely fail with its lawsuit.

Consensus after oral argument is that the court will end up in a 4-4 split, which would block DAPA from being implemented.  There have been times where the consensus after oral arguments has been wrong.  There is a possibility that either Kennedy and or Roberts will end up siding with the liberals on one of the questions in the case.  The court will decide both the standing of Texas as well as the legality of the executive action, so there are a number of possibilities for a somewhat surprising outcome.  Both Kennedy and Roberts are fairly close to 50% reverse/affirm on fantasy scotus, so I have a hard time putting the odds of reversal much below 50%.
Supreme Court is 4-4. The Republican senate leader has promised to veto any democratic leaning judge, so odds are low.

I have just lost 4 extensive drafts so I attempted to address this question systematically
bottom line, I just do not see either Kennedy or Roberts doing anything substantive on the case until there is are 9 Justices.

As it's already been established, SCOTUS is divided on this issue. Last year, a federal judge blocked implementation of Pres. Obama's Executive Action on Immigration, which included the DAPA program, on what were called "narrow technical grounds."  A  federal appeals court subsequently blocked it on broader grounds by a 2-1 vote.

From @lsgold7, I get the impression that this is unlikely, but FantasyScotus and {Marshall}+ both say the lower court decision will be reversed (by 5-3 and 8-0, respectively https://fantasyscotus.lexpredict.com/case-prediction/us-v-tx/).  The decision could be reversed after inauguration day, or Obama might not have enough time to actually implement DAPA after the decision, but the crowd prediction of 10% still seems too low.

I have no idea what this question as currently worded means to the people who wrote it, if people did.  The little tagged-on sentence that follows the Q just makes it worse.  I have long ago given up seeking clarifications when they have botched one up even less badly than this one.  Pick a number.
As others have noted, a pattern of the 4-4 SCOTUS refusing to rule on cases is developing. http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/18/us/politics/consensus-supreme-court-roberts.html

Jeh Johnson has announced nothing more until court rules.
Today 4 to 4  split on  birth control rights of employees balanced against religious freedom of the poor Little Sister
Seehttp://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/15pdf/14-1418_8758.pdf
A pattern of  DELAYING RESOLUTIONS OF BIG CASES  DUE TO 4/4 SPLIT developing.
I think the court will push off until a new judge is nominated.
See United States House of Representatives v. Burwell. On Scotus blog.
Election year hot button issue decision with a skinny court?  Ha!

There are a near definite four votes in favor of the President/the E.O. and Justice Kennedy seemed skeptical that Texas had standing during the oral arguments.  If Kennedy rules that Texas does not have standing to bring this case would be the fifth vote and thereby allow implementation.
A 4-4 decision rescinds the directive and there is no way to implement this plan.  Which is good, this is a congressional issue and congress should resolve this issue with the President.
If Clinton wins maybe if the GOP Senate votes on Garland.
Lower forecast after SC session end: question can not close with a negative out come until 1/20/17.

I think the Supreme Court has been and will be very reluctant to set any wide-spreading and non-obvious precedents while there are only 8 justices.  A split decision will not set a precedent, but will uphold the lower courts decision.  Based on the questioning of the "two swing judges", it appears like a 4-4 split is most likely, making implementation prior to inauguration day difficult.

There are several ways in which DAPA would NOT be implemented before January 20:
1) Supreme Court fails to overturn Circuit Court opinion on case. For this to happen, at least four justices have to decide that the states have standing AND win on the merits. On merits, Kennedy seemed favorable to the states. In oral arguments, Alito & Roberts were clearly favorable to states on standing, Thomas silent, and Kennedy was silent. I think this boils down to whether Kennedy agrees with states on standing. Right now, I'm pegging this at about 60% Kennedy agrees with states, so 60% for a 4-4 vote (i.e., no implementation). 
2) The Supreme court rules for the administration, but implementation is blocked through some other means: another court challenge, a delay in implementation past September 30 PLUS Congressional budgeting for FY17 that prohibits spending on DAPA, or some other method. I'm going to peg this conditionally at 10%.

Supremes likely to be 4-4 on this issue, meaning lower court's injunction stands.    There is a slight chance that DAPA could be passed as legislation by the newly elected Congress in early January 2017, but the Dems would have to have won the House (so they would control the legislative agenda) as well as a large enough majority in the Senate (and enough of a humiliation of Trump at the polls) where there wouldn't be 40 Repubs to filibuster.   Unlikely.

Migrants need America, America needs immigrants as production resources. May be Democrats will support the Democrat. A small step would be interesting, especially when already raised the leg. Perhaps something will be provided which will help to reduce the flow of migrants (after the adoption of the program). Strengthening of Trump during election will be positive for process of implementation.

What a confusing question. I'm reducing it in my head to something like "will SCOTUS generally say 'no' to presidential power in this area?" Seems like a lot of top forecasters are making positive predictions -- more positive than their words will imply. I feel more optimistic than the crowd that SCOTUS will "take Obama's side", whatever that means, but I'm sticking close to consensus because I am confused.

This question reflects the sloppy thinking of the people who write this stuff:  Does "implemented" mean  a go-ahead from the Court, as implied by the subtitle, or some partial or complete administrative action to make something happen?  How is the subtitle helpful, especially if it's meant to be part of the scoring criterion and there isn't a "4-4 Supreme Court," as another question obviously contemplates?  What if part of the programme is given the Court's okey-dokey and some other parts aren't?
